Column Comment.0: OBLIGATION: a condition of commitment on the agreement which must be fulfilled.There are many types of obligations and the fulfillment of an obligation may require achange to the agreement. e.g. offset obligation, work commitment, section 96 etc.Obligations may be financial (rental payments) or non financial (drilling, reportingetc.)
Column Comment.1: OBLIGATION SEQ NO: Unique identifier for each part or occurrence of an obligation
Column Comment.2: CALCULATION SEQUENCE NUMBER: unique identifier for the calculation of theobligation. Sequence number allows a calculation requiring multiple rows to bestored.
Column Comment.3: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.4: CALCULATION FORMULA: the formula used for calculating the obligation.
Column Comment.5: OBLIGATION CALCULATION METHOD: the method used to calculate theobligation.
Column Comment.6: OBLIGATION CALCULATION POINT OF DEDUCTION: the point at which thecalculation is taken, such as at the wellhead.
Column Comment.7: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.8: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.9: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.10: REMARK: narrative remark about the obligation calculation.
Column Comment.11: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.12: SUBSTANCE IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a substance that can be describedeither chemically or in terms of composition. Elements, ions, isotopes, isomers,minerals, chemicals, solvents, production substances, hydrocarbons etc are all listed.Be advised that many applications and agencies may use the same term, but thedefinition and composition details may not be the same. Use the SUBSTANCE XREFtable to capture relationships between substances, such as similar substances.
Column Comment.13: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.14: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.15: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.16: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.17: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.18: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.19: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
